ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A solid introduction to directing for students who have either never done it before or have only tried it once and aren't quite sure what being a good director means. The slow pace of it (especially if the class is small) can sometimes be frustrating, but the skills you learn -- how to read the play, break it down into comprehensive beats and then stage it to convey your vision of it to the audience -- are invaluable and will prove useful in your career if you choose to pursue directing.

I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to be a "theater-maker" as a career. The class is not only useful for the conventional "Director," but for anyone who want to get a taste of what it's like to create new theater. I highly recommend the class to actors, who often need a dose of reality and a glimpse into what its like to be on the opposite side of the table. The class is not a walk-in-the-park when it comes to the workload. You are expected to prepare a writing assignment for nearly every class and keep a well-maintained journal, but the work rarely felt superfluous. Additionally, Toni is a great person in the Yale theater community to get to know: a valuable brain to pick!

If you want to learn how to approach a scene, or a play, from various angles as a director, then take this course. Professor Dorfman assigns a variety of exercises that really help the students tackle the job of directing in many different ways - some practical and some more intangible. You will also get to direct 2 scenes (and rework each of them 1 time) and get feedback from Professor Dorfman and the class.
